reviewText: Richard Pryor and Gene Wilder team up for their third film SEE NO EVIL,HEAR NO EVIL. They together starred in SILVER STREAK(1976) and STIR CRAZY(1980). Wally Carou(Pryor) is blind. David Lyons(Wilder) is deaf. Wally applies for a position as a sales associate in David's magazine stand. After a customer,Wally's bookie,is threateningly shot to death by a beautiful woman named Eve(Joan Severance),Wally and David witness the customer's dead body and are framed for the murder which they were not responsible for. There are many silly scenes in this film.One where David and Wally fake foreign accents. Also,when eating ice cream on cones in the park,Wally crowns David with his(Wally's) cone and in the last scene,in that same park,David does the same to Wally. It was so funny when David labeled Wally in another scene as a "blind egotistical ---hole who denies he can't see s--t". David and Wally end up framing Eve with the help of Wally's sister Adele(Kirsten Childs). Gene Wilder met his current wife while filming this movie in 1988. He was then married to comedienne Gilda Radner who died of ovarian cancer at age 42 in May 1989,the month this film was theatrically released. Stewart Copeland of the rock band The Police wrote the soundtrack music for this film. There's also a scene where Wally and David "go on a cable ride". Jim Belushi and Charles Grodin did the same in director Arthur Hiller's next film,TAKING CARE OF BUSINESS.

reviewText: This is a very moderate comedy which perhaps is meant to capitalize on the previous popularity of Stir Crazy by once more pairing its stars Gene Wilder & Richard Pryor.  Wilder plays a deaf man, while Pryor plays a blind man.  The pair meet and become unwittingly involved in a criminal enterprise over a rare and valuable gold coin.  The main bad guys are played by Kevin Spacey and Joan Severance.  Spacey is modestly good as a villain.  However, Severance, despite her knock-out body and a nice nude scene, is lackluster and almost drone-like in her portrayal of the vixen.  If you like Wilder & Pryor, as I do, this is worth a rental fee.  Otherwise, it's a fairly forgettable comedy.  Then, again, seeing the low budget prices for this selection on Amazon, it might be worth paying $4 or $5 for it to own.
summary: Not the best Wilder/Pryor pairing, but it's okay

reviewText: I saw this movie when it was in the theater in 1989. I liked it so much that I had to buy it on VHS. Gene Wilder and Richard Pryor star as two innocent guys-one deaf, one blind, and both are on the run for a murder they didn't commit! Add the wonderful talents of Joan Severance and Kevin Spacey, and you have the makings of one well scripted and very funny movie! Oh, and let's not forget Alan North as the police chief. The film's plot makes for a cops and robbers type of suspense. Of all of Gene Wilder's and Richard Pryor's works, "See No Evil, Hear No Evil" is as equally funny as "Silver Streak", which makes it a must buy!
summary: One of Wilder and Pryor's best!

reviewText: It is so hard to find good comedy these days... and this movie is one of them! (Well, this isn't new, but it's not THAT old. And I just came across it, so it's new to me.) This movie has everything a good comedy needs: two actors who play off each other extremely well, a plot that has not been used a hundred times before, and good sight gags. As a bonus, I don't think it's even a plot that has been used ten times before. A blind man and a deaf man working together to solve a murder... and they did it in a way that was respectful to individuals who have those disabilities. (Personally I think a blind man would be a little more competent... like not walk into traffic because he was too embarrassed to use his cane... but for the most part it seemed respectful to me.)As someone whose favorite type of movie is the kind that makes me think and analyze, I really need a movie that makes me laugh sometimes. And this movie made me laugh A LOT! Highly recommended.

reviewText: Yes I know this came after Stir Crazy and usually those movies that come after that try to catch the spark of the initial movie had don't normally work.  I am not saying this is a classic by no means, but it's Richard Pryor and Gene Wilder together again.  There are some funny moments but this could be considered an acquired taste.  On movie merit alone it isn't really that good, but if your a fan of Pryor and WIlder you should check it out.  I gave it 4 stars because I am a fan, but it probably deserved more of a 2.5 to 3 star rating.

reviewText: I've seen this film five times since it was first released.As I grow in age and watch this movie, I feel almost robbed that I wasn't either around, or old enough to appreciate the pure genius that both Gene Wilder and Richard Pryor held.This film is about a blind man (played wonderfully by Richard Pryor) who's down on his luck and in need of a job.  Luckily for him, a deaf newsstand owner (played with all the comic gusto he can muster by Gene Wilder) happens to be hiring.Pryor owes a bookie big time, and when the bookie comes looking for him at his new place of employment, chaos ensues because he's murdered.  Wally (Pryor) doesn't see it, and Dave (Wilder) doesn't hear it.  The murderers get away and Dave and Wally are suspected.  Their misson: clear their name.Craziness and hilarity ensue.Gene Wilder and Richard Pryor are two highly underrated talents before the camera.  The adventures that these two poor characters go through is something that a wide audience can enjoy.  The use of two ailments such as deafness and blindness is not exploited or made fun of, just used for great comic timing and situations.If you're a fan of great comedy, and pretty good action that features two comic geniuses, I highly suggest this film.

reviewText: This funny comedy stars comedion Pryor as a blind man and comedian Wilder as a deaf man, both of who are on the run for a murder which they didn't commit.  Chaous appropratly ensure, and this comedy is full of laugh out load gags, and comic situations.  One particular funny situation was when the police officer was trying to get a headshot of Wilder, but couldn't get him to look at her, because he couldn't hear her directions.  Though a bit vulgar and at times over the top, it's hilarious and never takes itself too seriously and makes for good laugh out loud fun.  Both  Pryor and Wilder are comediac geniuses and this movie showcases their talent.  A must see for some laugh out loud fun and gags, though defiantly not appropriate for young children.

reviewText: 'See No Evil, Hear No Evil' is an underrated gem from 1989 once again pairing the great comedy team of Gene Wilder and Richard Pryor in their 3rd film together. It is highly UN PC but never actually offensive and at time highly uproarious! With a great soundtrack by Stewart Copeland of 'Police' fame and expert direction from Arthur Hiller (Silver Streak) 'See No Evil, Hear No Evil' is an above average comedy that is in many ways just as good as 'Stir Crazy'. Give it a chance, it is bound to grow on you!With that said, this review is going to focus on the video and audio quality of this Blu ray presentation and not the film itself.'See No Evil, Hear No Evil' is simply GORGEOUS on Blu ray. I own hundreds of BD discs and this is without a doubt one of the best catalog transfers I have ever seen. Crystal clear, great color w/ original color timing, no motion artifacts, almost perfect contrast, and no DNR or edge enhancement. For this type of release you will just never see a better looking transfer. A nice healthy 32 Mbits average bit rate and an uncompressed 2.0 sound track that sounds great decoded to Dolby Pro Logic II.Honestly, I am blown away by the quality of the video here. If all my 80's films looked this good I would be in 7th Heaven. Easily outshines 95% of all the BD's I own. Hats off to whoever scanned this one! GREAT JOB!!!OK, I am blown away by the picture quality, how about the audio?Again, another winner here folks. Granted, we are only given the original stereo track, but it is 16 bit LPCM and uncompressed and sounds great. Music, effects and dialogue are all top notch. Nothing but quality here folks. What a welcome treat after many "dud" discs that cost an arm and a leg.Honestly, this Blu Ray presentation is a text book case for how to do it RIGHT on these minor catalog titles. REALLY GREAT!There are no special features of any kind, no trailers either. Subtitles ARE included.'See No Evil, Hear No Evil' is not likely to ever win any awards, but it is solid comedy and the chemistry between Richard and Gene is UNDENIABLE in this one folks.  Yes, it is very VERY UN PC, but it is a refreshing change and holds up to repeated viewings.  For the current asking price of well under 10 bucks this Blu ray is a real deal. It's a shame 'Stir Crazy' can't come close to the picture quality provided here.Marty G's most highest recommendation for fans of the actors, the film or both. You will NOT be disappointed!!

reviewText: Gene Wilder and Richard Pryor were one of the funniest duos in history.  They played off each other's neuroses, shortcomings and antics so well.  This movie has its moments, but alas, it was dampened by a weak plot and a premise too silly to be believed.Gene is deaf, Richard is blind.  Much of that material of mishap writes itself.  Richard's health was clearly deteriorating and it shows by his weight lose and lack of energy, now he's so crippled by MS he can't even talk.  Gene is funny and lovable as ever, but you wonder if he's having as much fun as he's supposed to because of Richard's off camera antics.  That one scene where he clearly had a hard on for that gal was pretty funny, and there are a few good one liners and scenes here and there, but it's a weak story with a dull ending.  This would be the last time they would team up together, and for obvious reasons they didn't want to go back.
summary: The last effort that sank like a stone

reviewText: This is, without a doubt, one of the funniest films I've ever seen.  It walks the line between clever and juvenile as far as humor goes, but what a flick!  Pryor and Wilder's chemistry is fantastic, as usual.  These two have got to be the best comedy duo ever.  They're both hilarious on their own.  Sure, it might be a little un-pc to get laughs from handicapped characters, but I really don't think the film exploits that angle all too much.  Most of the humor basically comes from alot of incidents of miscommunication.  Richard Pryor's performance of the blind man is scarily realistic and well done.  Wilder's once again the sarcastic wise guy he does so well.  Most people have seen this before, but if you haven't, you shouldn't wait another minute.  If you have seen it, see it again.  Why not?

reviewText: I remember seeing the trailer for this film as a kid, and even back then I thought the concept was interesting.  Twenty years later, I finally see the movie and it turns out to be more interesting than I thought.  Sure the music is awful, there is some exaggeration in plot believability, and the villians are extraordinarily cliche, but the comedy work between Pryor and Wilder turns out to be a winner.  They find a way to milk this blind/deaf concept continually in a way that manages to stay fresh for the most part, and the first half of the plot turns out to be quite good for a somewhat lowbrow comedy.  This must have been a particularly difficult movie to write for, and perhaps a more difficult movie to act in, but it all seems to come together, with the weird ending and the music being the only really intolerable features.  I swear the music almost gave me a headache.Recommended for Pryor or Wilder fans, and highly recommended for fans of both.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I like Richard Pryor and Gene Wilder, but they, along with the director and scriptwriter, are phoning it in here. This movie, which was released late in the careers of Pryor and Wilder, is so forgettable it will be fading quickly in your mind as the closing credits roll. Wilder and Pryor don't generate much chemistry together here, perhaps because their characters are so bland, or maybe it's the other way around. The only scene that made me chuckle was the bar fight. I'd recommend instead checking out earlier classic films with Pryor and/or Wilder in them.
summary: See no humor, hear no humor
